title: The hominoid-specific gene <italic>TBC1D3</italic> promotes generation of basal neural progenitors and induces cortical folding in mice
abstract: Cortical expansion and folding are often linked to the evolution of higher intelligence, but molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying cortical folding remain poorly understood. The hominoid-specific gene <italic>TBC1D3</italic> undergoes segmental duplications during hominoid evolution, but its role in brain development has not been explored. Here, we found that expression of <italic>TBC1D3</italic> in ventricular cortical progenitors of mice via <italic>in utero</italic> electroporation caused delamination of ventricular radial glia cells (vRGs) and promoted generation of self-renewing basal progenitors with typical morphology of outer radial glia (oRG), which are most abundant in primates. Furthermore, down-regulation of <italic>TBC1D3</italic> in cultured human brain slices decreased generation of oRGs. Interestingly, localized oRG proliferation resulting from either <italic>in utero</italic> electroporation or transgenic expression of TBC1D3, was often found to underlie cortical regions exhibiting folding. Thus, we have identified a hominoid gene that is required for oRG generation in regulating the cortical expansion and folding.
